Chapter 11, Part 5: The Assembly of the Appearance of Light
At that time, when the World-Honored One was about to enter the city, with the power of inconceivable spiritual penetrations,
in the sky, subtle and wonderful sounds emerged,
expounding various dhÄraá¹‡Ä« practices, causing the great assembly
to hear such words.
The limits of birth and non-birth, the quiescent flow and cessation,
to such dharmas, all able to penetrate and ultimately abide.
With the power of giving, ultimately to gather in, with the power of upholding precepts,
ultimately to accomplish, with the power of patience, ultimately to adorn,
with the power of vigor, ultimately to arouse, with the power of wisdom,
ultimately to proclaim.
Free from all written words, speech, and sounds, up to form and mind, ultimately pure.
Contaminated and uncontaminated, meaning and benefit, all empty and tranquil, ultimately pure.
Not relying on any existence, ultimately abiding,
In the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« samÄdhi.
Up to neutral, benefiting oneself and others, such characteristics,
Ultimately pure.
The dharmas of Å›rÄvakas, ordinary beings, and buddhas, also not abiding,
In the limit of the exhaustion of the eye, the limit of arising, the extreme limit, up to quiescence,
Such practices, ultimately tranquil.
If arising is non-arising, this is suffering, this is happiness, praise and slander, all completely abandoned.
Ultimate purity, ultimate illumination, the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« of emptiness,
is understood. This is abiding in the place where the Buddha practices,
this is abiding in the place where the Buddha plays, this is abidingğŸ”½in the supernormal powers of the buddhas, this is abiding
in the wisdom of the buddhas.ğŸ”½Abiding in such power of the limit of the exhaustion of the eye,ğŸ”½abiding in such power of the arising of the eye, abiding in such
power of the edge of the eye,
up to abiding in the power of quiescent extinction, the ear, nose, tongue, body,
up to the twenty-five dharmas such as name, are also like this.ğŸ”½This dhÄraá¹‡Ä« accomplishes the TathÄgata'sğŸ”½distinguished power.ğŸ”½This dhÄraá¹‡Ä« accomplishes such
powerful virtue.
Entering all the TathÄgatas' places of practice, abiding in all the TathÄgatas'
realms.
Departing from the firm mind, abiding in the practice of the Brahma Heaven, able to cause countless
hundreds of thousands of yaká¹£as and kumbhÄá¹‡á¸as to all give rise to joy.
Also causing countless gandharva multitudes and rÄká¹£asas
to love and delight in discipline.
As for the meaning of the phrases, they are unable to be proclaimed, not being the mental factors,
what is conceived of, and also not being what is upheld by the mental factors.
This dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is not obtained by the eyes, this dhÄraá¹‡Ä«ğŸ”½also does not reach the body. This dhÄraá¹‡Ä«
is not obtained by the eyes,
and also does not reach the place where the eyes function.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, up to names and so forth, the twenty-five dharmas, are also like this.
It is also said that regarding the eye, at the limit of exhaustion, at the limit of arising, at the limit of cyclic existence,
up to quiescent extinction, there is no self, no person, no sentient being, no enduring soul,
up to the non-existence of a pudgala.
Without characteristics, unconditioned, not coming, not going, such characteristics are all fully understood.
It is also said that one fully understands the eye of the nature of dharmas.

It is also said that one fully understands the eye accomplished through dharmas, the eye of wisdom, the eye of discernment, the eye of BrahmÄ, the eye of the gods.ğŸ”½The eye obtained through birth in the BrahmÄ world, the eye obtained through birth in the heavenly world, the eye of the ripening of karma in the BrahmÄ world,
the eye of the ripening of karma in the heavenly world, the eye born from the causes of the BrahmÄ world, the eye born from the causes of the heavenly world,
The eye of transformation of the celestial spirits, the eye of celestial diligence, the eye of inferior birth,
The eye of superior birth, the eye that abandons the world of Yama,
The eye of dragons and yakshas, the eye of kumbhandas, the eye of torment,
The eye that is not tormented, the eye of purity, the eye that is not pure,ğŸ”½The eye of vastness and narrowness, the eye of the shravaka vehicle, the eye of meditative concentration,
The eye of samadhi, the eye of the realm, the eye born from conceptualization,
The eye born from craving, the eye that abandons craving, the eye born from causes,
The eye not born from causes, the eye of association, the eye of non-association,
The eye born from the gateway, the eye not born from the gateway, the eye born from conditions,
The eye born from the gateway of causes, the eye not made of flesh, the eye of pure wisdom,
The eye of non-existence, the eye that cannot be obtained.
The ears, nose, tongue, body, up to the twenty-five dharmas such as name and form, are also like this.
At that time, the World-Honored One, in the sky, again emitted immeasurable
Subtle sounds, expounding the supreme dhÄraá¹‡Ä« Dharma.
All of this was the transformation of the TathÄgata.
The dhÄraá¹‡Ä« states:
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is attained by all buddhas,
Endowed with great majestic virtue, wisdom immeasurable.
Far removed from attachment, mindfulness is completely pure,
No form, no coming or going, not a direction or a location.
Signless, beyond verbal expression, transcending all conceptual proliferation,
Bodhisattvas diligently cultivate and ultimately attain coolness.
Even if one were to expound with hundreds of thousands of nayutas of verses,
One would not be able to reach the end of a single phrase.
Praised by the sages, pure and unstained,
All the assemblies give rise to utmost respect.
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, with the power of good dharmas,
Can destroy afflictions and enable one to attain victory.
Merit and wisdom vast like the ocean,
Accomplishing the power of patience, the mind is peaceful and unmoving.
Bodhisattvas always cultivate this, praised by the wise,
Abandoning poverty, they will obtain great wealth and treasures.
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« increases all merits,ğŸ”½Always adorning with the true words of emptiness,
Abandoning written words, it is called the nature of emptiness,
By abandoning the mind and consciousness, it is called the nature of dharmas.
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is free from defilements and always pure,
Abiding in true wisdom, manifesting various benefits,
Causing all sentient beings to rejoice and give rise to pure minds.
The immeasurable assembly of yaká¹£as, and the kumbhÄá¹‡á¸as,
Such kings of ghosts also give rise to great joy.
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is tranquil and free from conceptual proliferation,
Loving and delighting in sentient beings, universally bestowing peace and happiness.
For many hundreds of thousands of kalpas, always dwelling in the various destinies,
Performing immeasurable benefits, pure and unstained.
Perhaps with hundreds of thousands of verses, expounding the nectar-like Dharma,
Causing immeasurable sentient beings to all give rise to great joy.
The immeasurable buddhas of the past, with pure aspirations,
Thus, with this dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, always contemplate the nature of dharmas.
The assemblies of Åšakra, BrahmÄ, and various devas, nÄga kings, and asuras,
Hearing this dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, give rise to great joy in their minds.
In the lands where this dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is practiced,
There are always no calamities, illnesses, or worries.
All sentient beings, each and every one, are delighted,
Wishing for this dhÄraá¹‡Ä« to always abide in their minds.
Thus, with this dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, wherever the body and mind are,
In the throat, palate, lips, and tongue, it gives rise to immeasurable merit.
If one is able to always uphold it, one attains immeasurable merit,
Benefiting many sentient beings, causing them all to rejoice.
Thus, with this dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, one abandons all faults and evils,
Expounding the subtle Dharma, one attains inexhaustible eloquence.
Causing hundreds of thousands of sentient beings To all cut off doubts and confusion,
Crushing away all arrogance and pride, Attaining immeasurable merit and virtue.
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is a profound and secret Dharma,
The wise always contemplate it, Courageously and diligently cultivating and practicing it.
Wearing the armor of wisdom, Destroying and extinguishing afflictions and troubles,
Increasing merit and virtue, Delighting in it without ever being satisfied.
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is endowed with vast and great fame,
Able to understand the end and the endless, The edge of birth and the edge of non-birth.
With such wisdom, Various adornments,
Hundreds of thousands of tathÄgatas Respect and make offerings.
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is the light and action for the two-legged,ğŸ”½Relying on supreme concentration, Heading towards the path of bodhi,
Following along with tranquility and insight, Penetrating and understanding the uncontaminated wisdom.
With the power of the faculty of pure faith, the two hands are accomplished,
With the accomplishment of diligence and patience, the two breasts are accomplished,
The perfection of wisdom is the characteristic of the crown of the head,
The sÅ«tras are the threads that string together the garland of the four kinds of fearlessness.
The various merits cultivated in the past,
And innumerable parables, all adorn it.
Such a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is endowed with immeasurable merits,
At the beginning, end, limit, and limitless extent of the eyes.
Whether born or unborn, the limit and non-limit,
Tranquil and not tranquil, revolving and not revolving.
Non-existence and non-arising, quiescence and non-self,
No person, no life, and even no sentient beings.
Such immeasurable gates are all understood.
Ears, nose, tongue, body, mind, the six sense objects, and the four great elements,
Up to the names of the world and life, all are like this.
As praised above, the subtle dhÄraá¹‡Ä«,
The realm of the buddhas, with the supreme merit of tranquility,
The true meaning of the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, not expressed by words,
In accordance with the world, only provisionally spoken of with names.
At that time, the World-Honored One, together with the great assembly, arrived at the young man's house, set out seats, and took his place.

At that time, the young man Candraprabha, knowing that the Buddha was seated, personally brought forth subtle offerings and presented them to the TathÄgata and the great assembly. Those offerings were purely the fruits of the excellent roots of goodness born of the inconceivable power of the merit and virtue of meditative concentration.

When making these offerings, he did not do so for his own sake, but universally caused immeasurable sentient beings to set out toward enlightenment and attain great benefits. Those offerings were distributed everywhere, all sufficient.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had finished his meal, he addressed the youth Candraprabha in the assembly, saying:
Young man!
If good men and good women who abide in the Great Vehicle practice the provisions of giving, there are eighty kinds of supreme merits.
What are the eighty?
They are: maturing sentient beings, accepting with kind words, being endowed with excellent characteristics, having unimpaired faculties,
renouncing birth and death, realizing nirvana, exhausting the bonds, attaining supreme mastery,
being endowed with merits, adorning the Buddha-land, having a pure retinue, possessing great authority,

being endowed with wisdom, accomplishing the most supreme and excellent practices, perfecting the unsurpassed and unequaled practices, eliminating habitual tendencies, increasing the Tathagata's practice of omniscience, and having one's body and
relics be objects of worship for the worlds, sravakas, and pratyekabuddhas, destroying evil people,ğŸ”½and
It can cause human kings, devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, asura kings, garuá¸a
kings, and BrahmÄ kings to all give rise to pure faith, have great majestic virtue, proclaim sÅ«tras,
verses, prophecies, self-narratives, eulogies, parables, causes and conditions, past events,
past lives, extensive teachings, rare dharmas, and even doctrinal discussions, uphold and expound them without being
lazy, be unstinting in the Dharma, abide in the Buddha's path, be supreme in the world, have pure
name and form, realize the Dharma body, attain fearlessness, accomplish merit, overshadow
all non-Buddhists, possess the Dharma of good people, abandon the conduct of bad people, believe in the causes of merit and wisdom,
harmonize the Buddha's teachings, subdue the various mÄras, have no doubts regarding the blissful Dharma taught by the Buddha,
destroy evil desires, possess great majestic virtue, cultivate bodhisattva practices, attain supreme spiritual powers,
Abandoning birth and death, accomplishing sentient beings, praising boundless practices, embracing merits
, comforting sentient beings, enjoying the bliss of the Dharma, practicing generosity, entering the great gate of wisdom
, abiding in the stage of heat, with a determined lineage, practicing the acceptance of the Dharma, peacefully abiding in the Buddha's path
ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
Young man!
If good sons and good women cultivate the provisions of generosity, they will fully accomplish these eighty kinds of supreme merits.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½The great wise bodhisattvas,
fully endowed with the provisions of generosity,
have eighty benefits, which I have now briefly explained.
There are also various merits, immeasurable and difficult to conceive,
all arising from generosity, which I will now briefly proclaim.
You give equally, universally to the great assembly,
such are the provisions of generosity, which the wise should cultivate and practice.
The inconceivable aggregate of merit,ğŸ”½Adorning the body with excellent characteristics,
All of which are perfectly complete.ğŸ”½The place of birth, the family,
The country, the home,ğŸ”½Fame, color, and mind,
All of which are pure.ğŸ”½The transformations of the devas,
The palaces and female attendants,ğŸ”½Pure and unobstructed eloquence,
All arise from giving.ğŸ”½The excellent provisions of giving,
All the buddhas praise it,ğŸ”½This is precisely the initial
Abiding in enlightenment.ğŸ”½The bodhisattvas who are diligent
Have no doubts about giving,ğŸ”½Abiding in a resolute mind,
They diligently cultivate giving.ğŸ”½In this way, the mind of giving
Accomplishes excellent merit,ğŸ”½The bodhisattvas diligently cultivate and practice,
They will realize the enlightenment of the buddhas.ğŸ”½By the power of giving,
They accomplish excellent spiritual powers,
Shaking koá¹­is of lands, without harming any sentient beings.
Through giving, one can attract pure precepts and much learning,
Right faith and diligence, samÄdhi, and untainted wisdom.
Through giving, one can attract the faculties, powers, factors of enlightenment,
Right exertion and spiritual bases, and eliminate all habitual tendencies.
Through giving, one can attract pure and wonderful sounds,
In koá¹­is of lands, revealing boundless Dharma.
Through pure faith and giving, one quickly attains the supernormal cognitive abilities;
In order to accomplish the supernormal cognitive abilities, one should diligently practice giving.
Immeasurable celestial beings, hundreds of thousands of asuras,
Dragons, spirits, and yaká¹£as, with retinues surrounding them,
All riding wonderful towers, freely playing and enjoying themselves.
Such kings, seeing those who diligently practice giving,
And prepare seats for them to make offerings.ğŸ”½Those who practice giving like this
Will be endowed with great majestic virtue,
With the power of sovereign spiritual penetrations, and will be accepted by the devas,ğŸ”½KumbhÄá¹‡á¸a yaká¹£as,
All of whom will come to submit,
And also the gandharva hosts, who will present various kinds of music.
Robbers will give rise to a compassionate mind, and evil people will stay far away,
Precious wealth will not be lost, and the storehouses will all be filled.
Because of cultivating giving, one will accomplish the supreme provisions,
And even in regard to the Buddha's wisdom, one will not practice the teachings of non-Buddhists.
This person will be free from illness and affliction, and will guard the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s,
And attain all the supreme powers, all arising from giving.ğŸ”½Those who practice giving like this
Will cultivate the path to enlightenment,
And will not encounter bad friends, but will attain good friends of the same kind.
There are also bodhisattvas who accumulate the provisions of giving,
Attaining inconceivable dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s and wisdom.
With immeasurable verses, they expound the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s,
Without any obstruction whatsoever, not losing the original meaning.
The mind of vast enlightenment, the aspiration always firm and solid,
Endowed with pure precepts, abandoning the activities of MÄra.
Not attached to the pleasures of the five desires, diligently seeking right mindfulness,
The mind always free from delusion, not giving rise to craving and love.
Hatred and the afflictions are all truly understood,
In all realms, not attached, not deluded.
This person skillfully understands such afflictions,
And through the combination of causes and conditions, is able to give rise to faults.
Even up to the Buddha's teachings, whether causes or causal factors,ğŸ”½...
In this way, one can understand all the causes and functions.
Such a person can understand the ultimate nature of the eye,
Far removed from all delusions, unstained by the eye.
Such a person can understand the origin and limits of the eye,
The quiescent and the flowing, the non-existent and the unborn,
Up to the state of quiescence, such is the ultimate nature,
Far removed from all delusions, unstained by the eye.
Such a person can understand the conventional expressions regarding the future of the eye,
Provisionally established in accordance with the world, there is no reality within them.
Such a person can understand the conventional expressions regarding the past of the eye,
Provisionally established in accordance with the world, there is no reality within them.
Such a person can understand the origin and limits of the eye,
The quiescent and the flowing, the non-existent and the unborn,
Up to the cessation of cessation, such verbal expressions,
Are provisionally established in accordance with the world, and there is no reality within them.
This person can understand the verbal expressions of the front end of the eye,
Merely a combination of causes and conditions, without attachment to anything within.
This person can understand the verbal expressions of the back end of the eye,
Merely a combination of causes and conditions, without attachment to anything within.
This person can understand the edge and limit of the arising of the eye,
Tranquility and continued existence, non-existence and non-arising,
Up to the cessation of cessation, such verbal expressions,
Merely a combination of causes and conditions, without attachment to anything within.
This person can understand the verbal expressions of the front end of the eye,
The intrinsic nature is inexpressible, without defilement within.
This person can understand the verbal expressions of the back end of the eye,
The intrinsic nature is without representation, and there is nothing to be attached to within it.
This person can understand the origin and limit of the eye,
Tranquility and samsara, non-existence and non-arising,
Up to quiescent extinction, such words and phrases,
The intrinsic nature is without representation, and there is nothing to be attached to within it.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, mind, the six sense objects, and the four great elements,
Up to the names of the world and birth, all are like this.
This person can understand that desire is the Buddha's path,
The intrinsic nature is without distinction, and there is nothing to be attached to in desire.
The path of all buddhas should be sought in afflictions,
Knowing the nature is without distinction, this is entering the gate of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s.
It is said that desire is a dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, and a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is precisely desire,
Knowing the nature is without distinction, this is studying the gate of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s.
Thus, making offerings to greed is making offerings to the Buddha,
And by making offerings to the Buddha, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
This person can understand that anger is the Buddha's path,
With no difference in intrinsic nature, and is unstained by anger.
Anger is precisely the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, and the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is precisely anger.
Knowing that their natures are no different is learning the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to anger is also making offerings to the Buddha,
And by making offerings to the Buddha, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
This person can understand that delusion is the Buddha's path,
With no difference in intrinsic nature, and is unstained by delusion.
If one truly understands the limit of the nature of delusion,
Then one cultivates the Buddha's path and accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Delusion is precisely the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, and the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is precisely delusion,
Knowing the nature to be without distinctions, this is learning the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the Buddha,
Because of making offerings to the Buddha, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the Dharma,
Because of making offerings to the Dharma, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the Saá¹…gha,
Because of making offerings to the Saá¹…gha, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the precepts,
Because of making offerings to the precepts, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to diligence,
Because of making offerings to diligence, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to praise,
Because of making offerings to praise, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to delusion is making offerings to the Buddha's teachings,
Because of making offerings to the Buddha's teachings, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to delusion is making offerings to the nature of dharmas,
Because of making offerings to the nature of dharmas, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to delusion is making offerings to suchness,
Because of making offerings to suchness, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to delusion is making offerings to non-arising,
Because of making offerings to non-arising, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to delusion is making offerings to non-cessation,
Because of making offerings to non-cessation, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to delusion is making offerings to non-exhaustion,
Because of making offerings to non-exhaustion, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to delusion is making offerings to non-existence,
By making offerings to ignorance, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the boundless,
By making offerings to the boundless, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the three realms of existence,
By making offerings to the three realms of existence, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to quiescence,
By making offerings to quiescence, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to saá¹ƒsÄra,
By making offerings to saá¹ƒsÄra, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to non-saá¹ƒsÄra,
By making offerings to non-saá¹ƒsÄra, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to non-existence,
By making offerings to non-existence, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to non-arising,
By making offerings to non-arising, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to quiescence,
By making offerings to quiescence, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to non-coming,
By making offerings to non-coming, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to non-action,
By making offerings to non-action, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to conditioned phenomena,
By making offerings to conditioned phenomena, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to suffering and so forth,
By making offerings to suffering and so forth, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the wisdom of suffering,
By making offerings to the wisdom of suffering, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is the same as making offerings to the wisdom of accumulation.
By making offerings to the wisdom of accumulation, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is the same as making offerings to the wisdom of cessation.
By making offerings to the wisdom of cessation, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is the same as making offerings to the wisdom of the path.
By making offerings to the wisdom of the path, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is the same as making offerings to the wisdom of dharmas.
By making offerings to the wisdom of dharmas, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is the same as making offerings to the wisdom of kinds.
By making offerings to the wisdom of kinds, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the wisdom of non-arising.
By making offerings to non-arising, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, making offerings to ignorance is making offerings to the knowledge of extinction,
By making offerings to the knowledge of extinction, one accomplishes the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway.
Thus, for right exertion, mindfulness, and the bases of supernatural power,
The five faculties, five powers, seven factors of awakening, and eightfold path,
Along with Å›amatha, vipaÅ›yanÄ, and so forth,
In these nine kinds of dharmas, all are like this.
At that time the World-Honored One told the youth Candraprabha:
Good man!
If there are sentient beings dwelling in the Great Vehicle who wish to accomplish the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s as explained above, they should stay far away from eighty kinds of people.
What are the eighty?
Namely, those who kill their fathers, harm their mothers, kill arhats, have the intention to harm the Buddha's body,
Destroy the harmonious Sangha, those who have left home as thieves, those without male organs, those with two organs, and those with wrong views,
Wrong thoughts, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness,
wrong concentration, not knowing the place, not knowing the time, not knowing the Dharma, not knowingğŸ”½the path, not knowing the measure, not knowing oneself and others, not being able to respect
the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, as well as the precepts,

not being heedful and not revering the sublime realms, not knowing the Dharma,ğŸ”½not knowing the Vinaya, not knowing the precepts, not knowing the gravity of offenses, not knowingğŸ”½the transgressions of the precepts, not knowing the subtle and coarse practices, not knowing the future
and present karmic results, not understanding inferior matters, praising the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle and denigrating the TathÄgata's teachings,
encouraging and teaching the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, turning away from and abandoning the unsurpassed true path, breaking the precepts,
breaking views, breaking the various dignified deportments, practicing the wrong path, speaking of self, person,
There are sentient beings who speak of the existence of a life-force, speak of the existence of a pudgala, and have inferior aspirations,
giving rise to greed, hatred, and delusion, the view of annihilation, the view of permanence, the view of emptiness and no cause, not seeing existence,
not seeing non-existence, not seeing karma, not seeing diligence, not knowing karma, not
knowing the causes of karma, not knowing ripening, not knowing the causes of ripening, not knowing the faculties,
not knowing the causes of the faculties, not knowing the realms, not knowing the causes of the realms, not knowing liberation,
not knowing the causes of liberation, not knowing the path, not knowing the causes of the path, not knowing afflictions,
not knowing the causes of afflictions, not knowing giving, not knowing the causes of giving, not knowing the past and future,

not knowing the causes of the past and future, not knowing birth and death, not knowing the causes of birth and death, not knowing contaminated [dharmas], not knowing the causes of contaminated [dharmas], not knowing exhaustion and non-exhaustion,
Not knowing existence and non-existence, not knowing the limit and non-limit, not knowing tranquility and non-tranquility,
not knowing transformation and non-transformation, not knowing nature and non-nature, not knowing birth and non-birth,
not knowing cessation and non-cessation.
Young man!
If good men and good women wish to accomplish the above-mentioned dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, they should abandon these eighty kinds of unwholesome people.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
If one does not understand the eye, the limit of the exhaustion of birth,
this person is confused about dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, the wise should stay far away from them.
If one can understand the eye, without self and without sentient beings,
this person abides in dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, the wise should be close to them.
If one can understand the eye, born exhausted, free from words and letters,

Greed, anger, delusion, resentment, arrogance, jealousy, deceit, stinginess, worry and distress,
Faults, defilements, poisonous arrows, violent currents, black and white karma,
Do not arise and do not cease, do not go and do not come,

Knowing the past and future of the eyes, far removed from annihilation and permanence,
The nature of causes and conditions is empty, as the guide skillfully explains.
When expounding the Dharma, if one discriminates the characteristics of the eyes,
This person is falsely discriminating and is not called a true expounder of the Dharma.
When contemplating the Dharma, if one discriminates the characteristics of the eyes,
This person is falsely discriminating and is not called one who contemplates the Dharma.
When cultivating the Dharma, if one discriminates the characteristics of the eyes,
This person's false discrimination is not called cultivating the Dharma.
If one understands the empty nature of the eyes, one does not proceed to bodhi.
The buddhas always appear before this person and speak the Dharma.
If one does not understand the eyes, one also does not understand form.ğŸ”½If one can understand the eyes, one also understands form.
If one can understand the eyes, one also understands form.
If one understands form, one can also understand the eyes.
The ears, nose, tongue, body, mind, the six sense objects, and the four great elements,
Up to the names of the world and birth, all are like this.
When expounding the Dharma, discriminating the characteristics of causes,
This person's false discrimination is not called expounding the Dharma.
When expounding the Dharma, discriminating the characteristics of tranquility,
This person's false discrimination is not called expounding the Dharma.
If when expounding the Dharma, one discriminates the characteristics of the path,
This person is falsely discriminating, and is not called expounding the Dharma.
If when expounding the Dharma, one discriminates the characteristics of emptiness,
This person is falsely discriminating, and is not called expounding the Dharma.
If when expounding the Dharma, one discriminates accumulation,
This person is falsely discriminating, and is not called expounding the Dharma.
If when expounding the Dharma, one discriminates phenomena and things,
This person is falsely discriminating, and is not called expounding the Dharma.
If when expounding the Dharma, one discriminates the grasping of the eye,
This person is falsely discriminating, and is not called expounding the Dharma.
If one does not understand the eye, then desire arises;
If one can understand the eye, desire will not arise.
The ears, nose, tongue, body, mind, the six sense objects, and the four great elements,
Up to the name of worldly birth, all are like this.
When expounding the Dharma, distinguishing various fruits,
This person falsely discriminates and is not called expounding the Dharma.
Not regressing in aspiration, comprehending the emptiness of nature,
Attaining the various samÄdhi gates, they are able to skillfully expound the Dharma.
Not regressing in aspiration, with regard to the eye, free from discrimination,
Because of non-discrimination, they are able to skillfully expound the Dharma.
Not comprehending the emptiness of the eye's nature, also deluded regarding the eye's intrinsic nature,
Because of not comprehending, this is not suitable for expounding the Dharma.
If comprehending the emptiness of the eye's nature, then knowing the eye's intrinsic nature,
Because of being able to comprehend, this person is suitable for expounding the Dharma.
Not comprehending the emptiness of the eye's nature, also deluded regarding the intrinsic nature of the phrase,
Because of not comprehending, this is not suitable for expounding the Dharma.
If one understands the empty nature of the eye, one will know the self-nature of the phrase,
Because of being able to understand, this person should expound the Dharma.
If one does not understand the empty nature of the eye, one will also be confused about the self-nature of the text,
Because of not being able to understand, this person should not expound the Dharma.

Because of being able to understand, this person should expound the Dharma.

Because of not being able to understand, this person should not expound the Dharma.
If one understands the empty nature of the eye, one will know the self-nature of the name,
Because of being able to understand, this person should expound the Dharma.
If one does not understand the empty nature of the eye, one will also be confused about the self-nature of form,
Because of not being able to understand, this person should not expound the Dharma.
If one understands the empty nature of the eye, one will know the self-nature of form,
Because they are able to understand, these people should expound the Dharma.
Not understanding the emptiness of the nature of the eye, relying on worldly characteristics to discriminate,
They are unable to skillfully follow along and subdue sentient beings.
If one understands the emptiness of the nature of the eye, not relying on characteristics to discriminate,
Then one is able to skillfully follow along and subdue sentient beings.
Not understanding the existence or non-existence of the eye, expounding the Dharma while in the assembly,
This person is greedy for offerings, and no one will believe or accept it.
If one understands the existence or non-existence of the eye, expounding the Dharma while in the assembly,
This person is not attached, and everyone will believe and accept it.
Not understanding the emptiness of the nature of the eye, while sitting on the Dharma seat,
Although speaking many parables, no one will believe or accept it.
If one understands the emptiness of the nature of the eye, while sitting on the Dharma seat,
The parables that are spoken, everyone will believe and accept.
Ears, nose, tongue, body, mind, the six sense objects, and the four great elements,
Up to the names of worldly existence, all are like this.

At that time, after the World-Honored One had spoken this sutra, Prince Moonlight and the great assembly, all the worldly beings, devas, humans, asuras, gandharvas, and so forth, having heard the Buddha's words, greatly rejoiced, and with faith and understanding, they practiced accordingly.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
